Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Provenance of Alkenones & Holocene Temperature Evolution of the NW Atlantic
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will produce a set of 12 new sea-surface temperature reconstructions along the western North Atlantic to examine the accuracy of alkenone-based ocean temperature records. Temperature data over the past several thousand years show a mismatch between land-, sea-, and climate model-based estimates. Climate models suggest that temperature remained relatively unchanged, while land-based records shows slight warming. Oddly, sea surface temperatures show 4-6°C cooling over the same period of time. But concerns exist about how well these records reflect temperature conditions in the region. Alkenones are produced by algae which may be biased by the temperature of the season when algae are most abundant. They can also be carried to the North Atlantic from elsewhere by ocean currents and reflect temperature conditions of those regions. This study will attempt to resolve these issues by examination of alkenones collected directly in the water column throughout the year and comparing these to alkenones deposited on the seafloor nearby. Hydrogen isotope ratios and radiocarbon data will provide a test of how much material is transported from different sources. Alkenone temperature data will be compared to other temperature proxies (e.g. Mg/Ca of foraminifera) in the region. The project creates significant learning opportunities for middle and high school teachers who will team with scientists in the classroom to develop climate-based curricular instruction and participate in shipboard research during sediment coring operations. It will also provide significant support for undergraduate students and an early career postdoctoral student. <br/><br/>The global composite of Holocene temperature proxy records indicates 0.5-1°C of cooling over the last 8,000 years, driven largely by a 2°C cooling in northern hemisphere marine records. Transient climate simulations, however, show no such cooling, and continental temperature records in eastern North America and Europe indicate slight warming. This “Holocene Conundrum” is one of the most prominent unmet challenges facing the climate science community. The northern hemisphere trend is largely driven by 4-6°C cooling in three alkenone SST records from the NW Atlantic. To determine whether this data-model mismatch indicates a gap in understanding of the climate system, these anomalous proxy records must be examined in the context of the factors influencing alkenone deposition in NW Atlantic slopewaters and compared to other SST proxies in the same locations for which samples are not available and analyses are presently lacking. Both deficiencies will be addressed in this research by measuring hydrogen isotope values and radiocarbon ages of alkenones, along with Mg/Ca ratios in planktonic foraminifera, from sediment cores and archived sediment trap samples collected in 2004-2007 in the NW Atlantic slopewater region. Alkenone SST records can be biased by lateral transport of slow-sinking alkenones via surface and abyssal currents, or by seasonal production, both potential causes for the data-model mismatch. This project will take advantage of the large hydrogen isotope gradient in NW Atlantic surface waters to ascertain alkenone synthetic provenance by measuring 2H/1H ratios in alkenones. Provenance will be further assessed by measuring alkenone 14C ages to determine the extent of pre-aging during advection. Comparison of alkenone temperatures and 14C ages to fast-sinking, foraminiferal Mg/Ca temperatures and calcite 14C ages, across a series of locations and depths, with seasonal resolution, will allow for the full characterization of advective or seasonal biasing in either proxy relative to in situ and satellite SSTs. Having established the impact of these potential biases, a robust re-assessment of NW Atlantic Holocene SSTs will be made via 12 new reconstructions (6 each from the two independent proxies) from 6 planned coring sites on depth transects east of New Jersey and Nova Scotia, allowing a possible solution to the “Holocene conundrum”.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate reconstructions of past ocean surface temperatures are important for characterizing the range of natural climate variability and for validating climate models. Global temperature reconstructions spanning the last 10,000 years show a long-term cooling trend that is generally not reproduced in models forced with orbital geometry, ice sheets, and greenhouse gases, suggesting a shortcoming in our understanding of the climate system that must be resolved. However, the cooling trend disappears if a handful of sea-surface temperature reconstructions based on phytoplankton lipids known as alkenones from the North Atlantic Ocean are removed.

The scientific objective was to verify the marine-based paleotemperature proxy based on alkenones, to assess their accuracy and determine if distally-produced were transported by currents by comparing them to and foraminifera based SST.  Determining to what extent lateral transport affects SST reconstructions will inform reconstructions on the strength and influence of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) on Paleo-SST reconstructions in the region.

 

The Field work objective of the project work was to obtain a new suite of cores from the Northwest Atlantic shelf slope off of Nova Scotia and New Jersey, that would be suitable for improving understanding of Holocene sea surface temperatures (SST) in the region. The project was successful in obtaining cores suitable for the study. Four cores from depths of 200 m to 3400m were obtained off of Nova Scotia and three from depths of 110 m to 200m off of New Jersey

An important component of utilizing new unstudied cores is establishing their stratigraphy, that is, converting depth-down core to an estimate of time using geochemical markers. Shore-based stratigraphic analyses determined a number of cores were suitable for detailed glacial-timescale paleoceanographic study. Determining that some cores had high enough resolution guided the choice of cores three for further work and initial SST estimates based on alkenones were conducted.  Unfortunately, there were insufficient foraminifera in in any of the cores to obtain paired SST estimates based on the microfossils. Consequently, this aspect of the project pivoted to a grain-size analysis study that provided bottom current speed estimates to provide information on lateral transport that will be used to complement the alkenone SST analyses.  

 

The sea-going aspect of this project was dubbed “PUFINS” for “Paleo Unsaturated-alkenone Fluxes in Northwest Atlantic Sediments” to provide an affectionate mascot and easy to remember acronym.  The broader impact objectives of this work involved outreach to engage 4 middle and high school teachers. They participated on board the cruise in the science aspects. Their outreach efforts aboard the cruise involved them conducting live-streamed video sessions with their students and other groups.  They also created online content that was posted to the cruise blog site:  https://sites.rutgers.edu/pufins-at-sea/ .  Within 6 months of the cruise the site had 7375 hits.

The associated facebook page for “PUFINS” at sea.  https://www.facebook.com/rutgerspufins  had 34,000 hits within 6 months and the Instagram account had 11,000 hits in the same time frame.  

Each of the teachers after the cruise created lesson plans based on the experience and One teacher presented lesson plans based on the samples and concepts from the voyage at the New Jersey Science Teachers Association  annual meeting: https://njsta.org/event-4968127

 

This work supported two post-docs and supplied samples for a summer intern undergraduate student. The grain size analysis was presented at the Ocean Sciences meeting in New Orleans in February 2024.
